title: What percentage of aspiring authors get published? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m assuming you’re referring to being published by a traditional (= real) publisher? Of all the people who now “publish” (self-publish, or indie publish, and I am one of them), perhaps 0.00001% are traditionally published. Or at least that’s what it seems to me. Millions of people self-publish now. Literally millions. The population of the Earth (just Googled it) is 7.7 billion — it’ll probably be 7.8 by the time I finish writing this. lol Do some math and you’ll see that I’m not all that far off, am I? And how many people are out there are saying, “Oh, I really want to write a book some day.” Count those in and the odds get closer to being something like 0.0000000001% of “aspiring” writers. Because these latter folks are never going to get down and actually write one, they will forever only “aspire” to write one. I said that I self-publish. Well, I started typesetting (part of the publishing world) in 1969. That would be fifty years ago. I also learned design, etc., through those years. My career went extinct when Bill Gates came along with Microsoft and introduced desktop publishing. I was out of a career ca. 1989. Why pay me (at the time $18/hr) when your little Susie Secretary will do it for you for $4 an hour? And who cares about all those thousands of nitty gritty little design and grammar rules, eh? Let’s just pretend they don’t exist. We’ll brainwash the world into thinking that there’s no difference between there, they’re and their. (It’s working, isn’t it? :-D) I am an old lady now (almost 75) but I still remember every single little nuance of publishing, editing and especially design. That’s mostly because I still work at it. I do my own books all the way through, and I edit, design and sometimes even publish other authors’ books, too. I don’t edit anymore, though — only for a couple of friends. I have too many books of my own to do and not that many years left to do them in. I design books only for members of the local branch of my national writing group (Canada). And not for free. (I get my own books edited by someone else before I publish and I have several people read them for glitches, etc. And not for free either.) And I’m very fussy about what books my logo goes on so I don’t recommend you ask. Sorry. So much to do, so little time. With ALLLL that being said, write anyway. Get those books written and save all those MSs (manuscripts) up on a Cloud or in a safety deposit box or somewhere else safe. One day you’ll figure out how KDP Amazon and its ilk work and you can go out there and get “published” with yourself as the pubisher. And you will have already written ALLLL those manuscripts, right? And with all that practice, you’ll have learned how to write a good one (and how to fix the first few you “practised” with). Keep writing no matter what. Sherrill

The statistics I used to hear were that of 5000 manuscripts crossing an agent’s/publisher’s desk in a year, depending on the size of their publishing house, they might publish 5–10 of them. But keep in mind with these statistics, that when people start writing, the ones ones who get as far as completing their story and send it off, the vast majority are literally sending off their first draft of their first story, where editing isn’t even always as much as getting rid of the typos or ensuring the format is what has been asked for, or that the genre is one they are interested in. It’s like writing your first essay at university and sending it off expecting to be granted your PhD. And the agents/publishers can see this. Like everything, if you want to be good at it, it’s a long journey with a lot of practice and learning. I mean, would you go to a doctor for surgery at the end of their first term of study? If you look at the statistics of those who have spent the time and done the hard work, and are actually sending in a polished and professional manuscript, the statistics are way different. The ones who do get published have generally already discarded a few stories. They have spent years writing millions of words, and working out how to do it better. They have spent time getting feedback, and squeezed out the hours around life. They have re written that particular manuscript maybe dozens and dozens of times. If you look at just these manuscripts the statistics are way different. If you’re one of the ones who are persevering with the task, I think it’s important to keep this in mind.
